turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm looking for some new music to listen to. I'm really into indie rock, any suggestions?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Sure! Based on your preference for indie rock, I can recommend some artists. Have you heard of bands like The Strokes, Arctic Monkeys, or The Killers? They're pretty popular in that genre.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yeah, I know all those. I'm looking for something a bit more...obscure, maybe some newer bands or something less mainstream. Anything good out there that isn't overplayed?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, I understand. Let me see... Have you checked out bands like Fontaines D.C. or Wet Leg? They've been getting a lot of buzz lately, and they're definitely on the indie rock spectrum but with a more modern sound. I can also suggest Black Country, New Road. They are quite unique.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hmm, I've heard of Fontaines D.C., but not the others. Is there a way to quickly find out the common aspects of those bands, in terms of their musical style or the instruments they use?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a great question. Let me cross-reference the information I have on these bands... *pauses briefly* Okay. Based on the available data, all three bands blend elements of post-punk, art rock, and indie rock. They all use electric guitars, bass, and drums as core instruments, although Wet Leg tends to be more pop-oriented and less complex in their arrangement. Black Country, New Road, employs violins and saxophone more extensively, which gives their sound a unique twist.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, this is really helpful, thanks! I'll check them out. What about something a little different? Maybe some indie folk?
